column4: Does anyone here know how to reset the Xorg.conf file from the command line after it has been backed up then changed?
I dont know the path's, I screwed up my Xorg.conf file and I can only get the command line when I boot Ubuntu now. I am using Puppylinux now.
so you don't know where the backup is?
It is backed up in the default place that Ubuntu would back it up in, but I have no idea where that is.
I gave the command 'sudo nvidia-glx-new enable' figuring that would render better, and Ubuntu automatically made a backup of my Xorg.conf file.
you do this 'cd /etc/X11'.  Then list what you see with 'ls'.  Then look for the backup (will be xorg.conf.blahblahblah or similar).  Then 'cp xorg.conf.blahblahblah xorg.conf'
Thanks, will be back if it doesn't work.
X, Xserver, xorg.conf, display-session-options, and some other stuff, but nothing to do with the .conf file.

I don't know then.  You'll have to try reading the documentation for the nvidia driver or consult google to see where it creates the backup.  Better approach: just make a new one with 'sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg'
or 'sudo dpkg-reconfigure -phigh xserver-xorg' for less questions
not quite, it will ask you for the driver you want to use
I don't know the driver I want to use though, I've only been using Linux for a month.**
nv is the normal one for nvidia cards (not proprietary)
